name: DevSecOps
description: DevSecOps methodology for secure and fast delivery through collaboration between Development, Security, and Operations.

name: Data Strategy
description: Church-wide strategy for organizing, enabling, and protecting data to increase its value and ensure compliance.

name: Application & Code Security
description: Initiative to establish best practices and unified strategy for application and code security.

name: IoT Devices
description: Committee assessing risks and benefits of IoT devices and recommending processes to maximize value and minimize risk.

name: Resiliency and Availability
description: Program to enhance fault tolerance and disaster recovery for critical Church systems.

name: Metadata Standards
description: Committee to define metadata standards for identifying and managing critical data elements.

name: Disaster Recovery
description: Technical capability to recover systems to standby environments when availability fails.

name: Data Sovereignty
description: Strategy to ensure data complies with local laws and governance while supporting global operations.

name: Generative AI
description: AI algorithms that generate new content; includes risks of bias, IP concerns, and misinformation.

name: Confidential Computing
description: Protects data in-use using hardware-based Trusted Execution Environments (TEE).

name: Observability
description: Advanced monitoring to understand system behavior and dependencies using telemetry and OpenTelemetry standards.

name: Software Bill of Materials (SBOM)
description: Inventory of third-party packages in software to identify vulnerabilities and license risks.

name: Cloud-native Architecture
description: Architecture patterns that leverage full capabilities of cloud platforms like AWS and Azure.

name: Digital Accessibility
description: Designing technology to be accessible to all users, aligned with ADA and WCAG standards.

name: AngularJS
description: Frontend web app framework.

name: Anthill
description: The official end of life date for Anthill will be 8/31/2023. If you have any projects currently being built in Anthill with the repo in Bitbucket, Bitbucket has an EoL date of 5/31/2023. If you need help in migrating from Anthill to Azure DevOps please email alm@churchofjesuschrist.org with the project name and will be happy to assist.

name: AppDynamics
description: AppDynamics has been replaced by Dynatrace, which is an application performance monitoring (APM) platform utilizing AI and automation, for both on-premise and cloud-based applications.

name: Artifactory on-prem
description:
Use Artifactory for hosting, managing, and distributing binaries and artifacts.

Migrate from the on-prem to cloud version of Artifactory.

name: AutoMapper
description:
AutoMapper is a .NET library which has transitioned from open-source to paid licensing.

 

AutoMapper is a .NET library that defines object-to-object mappings and handles data transfer based on those rules.

 

Alternative open-source libraries:

- Mapperly (recomended)

- Mapster

- ValueInjector

- ask AI to generate the left-right mapping code

 

Find more alternatives: https://www.google.com/search?q=automapper+alternatives

name: AWS - Enterprise (myapps.microsoft.com)
description: We have reached a hard limit with the number of SAML-enabled roles we can create using our direct SAML integration. All new SAML roles will now only be provisioned through AWS Identity Center. Existing roles will be availble through the AWS - Enterprise application in myapps.microsoft.com in the interim, but the direct SAML integration will be disabled later this year. All teams should migrate to the AWS - Identity Center - Enterprise application as soon as possible.

name: aws-azure-login
description: aws-azure-login is a 3rd party npm package that is no longer maintained or supported. Due to the increasing number of issues and security vulnerabilities, we recommend you migrate to the newer, AWS-managed Identity Center SSO login.

name: Azure Data Studio
description: Azure Data Studio is being deprecated 2/26/26.  Migrate to VS Code with mssql extension or SSMS v21

name: Azure Repos
description:
Project teams are encouraged to use Github Teams for repository grouping and to simplify access management. 


ALMTeam Github Teams example
  • Under settings for the ALM Team the parent Team was set to Portfolio-Enterprise Services Management (Dept-Information Communication Services > Div-Technology and Platform Services > Portfolio-Enterprise Services Management > ALMTeam).
  • ALMTeam has 8 members and 9 associated repositories.

name: BitBucket
description: Offline but available for read-only, temporary access to allow code migration. Under no circumstances will write permissions be enabled.

name: Cloudability
description: Monitoring tool for Cloud spend

name: eDirectory (IDV and GDIR)
description: LDAP clients should make every effort to move away from using the LDAP protocol during 2025 and 2026.  Exceptions that believe there is a need to delay beyond 2026 will need to obtain an exception from the Division Directors in the IAM Steering Committee.

name: Enzyme
description: Enzyme is a JavaScript Testing utility for React

name: External Database Connections with Missionary Systems
description: Switch to MGQL

name: Flood.io
description:
Load testing tool.
Flood.io which has been used for conference load testing is end-of-life on June 30th of this year.
Azure Load Test has been evaluated and determined to be a good simple-to-use replacement for Flood.io.
The QA Stack team (Shaun) and committee are evaluating performance testing options.

name: Fluent Assertions (open source unit testing library)
description:
Fluent Assertions is an open-source .NET library used for making assertions in unit tests independent from the unit test framework. It was recently purchased by a corporation (Xceed) and is no longer available under a free open source license (previously Apache 2.0) for non-commercial use.

This change was made in January 15, 2025. Please migrate off of Fluent Assertions as soon as possible.

We recommend migrating to Shouldly (see https://github.com/shouldly/shouldly/issues/1034 on how to migrate). AwesomeAssertions (https://github.com/AwesomeAssertions/AwesomeAssertions) is a community fork and has a high risk of being abandoned in the future, but may be a good short term solution. You may also choose to ditch an independent assertion library and use native assertsions within your unit test framework (NUnit, xUnit, etc.)  

Reference:
https://xceed.com/products/unit-testing/fluent-assertions/
https://github.com/fluentassertions/fluentassertions/blob/main/LICENSE
https://xceed.com/fluent-assertions-faq/
https://www.nuget.org/packages/FluentAssertions 

NOTE: Credit to Rob Richardson for reporting this license change

name: Integration Point
description: Wiki for technical documentation. Read-only March 31 and EOL end of 2024

name: Jama
description: Requirements tracking tool

name: Java 8 Lambda
description:
The Java 8 Lambda runtime was deprecated on Jan 8, 2024. Block function create was blocked on Feb 8, 2024 and Block function update will be blocked on Feb 28, 2025.

After a runtime is deprecated, AWS may no longer apply security patches or updates to that runtime, and functions using that runtime are no longer eligible for technical support. Such deprecated runtimes are provided ‘as-is’, without any warranties, and may contain bugs, errors, defects, or other vulnerabilities.

name: Jest
description:
after September 1, the Jest testing framework will no longer be compatible with the node.js versions supported by Cloud Foundry. This change will affect 175 repos. We recommend that you complete the upgrade by August 31 to avoid any disruptions to your build and deploy process.

 

Why are we doing this?  

  • ?The Front-end Stack team has been using Jest to perform unit/component testing for nearly a decade now. On May 11, 2022, Meta transferred ownership of the Jest library to the OpenJS Foundation.  Without Meta backing the maintenance and upkeep of Jest, the library has fallen behind.  There has not been a production release of Jest for two years.  ?

  • We are now at the point that the Jest library will not support the latest version of Node.js. On September 1, the Cloud Foundry team has a published update that will move our on-premise servers to the LTS version of Node.js. This update will cause Jest to fail the build process during code testing and deployments. 

 

Why did we pick Vitest?

  • Given the ongoing lack of industry support of Jest and the need to update the Node.js version, we are proposing the use of an open-source library named Vitest. Vitest is similar to Jest, has strong industry support and should be a viable alternative for years to come.

  • The Stack Team has updated the festack-scripts with Vitest and has created a migration guide for teams to follow.  The Stack team will provide both transition support and support for Jest as teams work this into their development cycles. 

 

What Happens if I don’t upgrade?

  • After the Cloud Foundry team publishes their build pack update (around September 1), the pipeline builds will fail, preventing you from building and deploying your application.

  • If you don’t want to upgrade, you can point to an older node.js build pack

name: Jira on-prem
description:
For Jira users who have lead or admin permissions in a project they will receive access to a spreadsheet to provide migration related information. The ALM team needs to know if a project needs to be migrated and the appropriate migration window.

Teams can consider moving to Azure Boards as an alternative to Jira Cloud.

name: KeyAccess
description:
KeyAccess is an Identity Governance solution that is being migrated from and eventually replaced by “UserAccess” provided by SailPoint's Saas solution.

This will be done in two phases. The initial phase is to move over the existing functionality for 90 plus percent of the customers that use KeyAccess.

Customers that use KeyAccess to request access to IAN access, Database access, Service Account requests, or to Workforce Enable a non-HR managed as they do today until we tackle phase two, which is slated for Q2 of 2025.

For migrating off of key access, there shouldn't be any work on your side to be done.

name: LastPass
description: The organization’s contract ended with LastPass, and due to security breaches, the organization decided to look for a better password manager. After extensive testing, 1Password fit our needs the best.

name: LDAP, Kerberos, Basic Auth
description: LDAP clients should make every effort to move away from using the LDAP protocol during 2025 and 2026.  Exceptions that believe there is a need to delay beyond 2026 will need to obtain an exception from the Division Directors in the IAM Steering Committee.

name: MediatR
description:
MediatR is a .NET library which has transitioned from open-source to paid licensing.

 

MediatR is a .NET library that allows loosely coupling components. One code publishes, another method consumes. This can help avoid circular dependencies between projects and dlls.

 

If you architect your system correctly, you can avoid circular dependencies by separating concerns properly. You may not need this library.

 

If you need this separation of concerns and don't use a pub/sub queue to also gain hardware resilience and request responsiveness, you can find other open-source alternatives.

name: Mongoose Cadence
description: Mongoose Cadence is used by Philanthropies for donation collection. It will be replaced by GiveCampus.

name: Okta dev tenant product EOL
description:
Okta is changing their dev tenant model. Replacing it with Integrator Free Plan. Impact to all teams using okta dev tenants starting July 18th. 

 

All users of dev tenants will need to adjust, and existing dev tenants will "begin to be deleted July 18th." We don't have more information on that deletion. 

The new program provides free tenants for development, with a major caveat that they are limited to 10 user accounts.  If a team needs a tenant with more than 10 user accounts, we can request Okta create a "Preview" tenant, which will not have that limitation.

Okta provides a migration tool but it has an issue with importing. Teams will likely need to start fresh in the Integrator Free environments.

 

Our guidance is on https://confluence.churchofjesuschrist.org/spaces/IA/pages/273319427/Okta+Integrator+Free+Plan+Tenants

See https://confluence.churchofjesuschrist.org/x/A4ZKE for a migration plan. 

 

See https://support.okta.com/help/s/article/introducing-integrator-free-orgs for Okta announcement.

name: Omnichannel for Dynamics 365 Customer Service
description:
Omnichannel for Customer Service was officially retired on June 30, 2024. The app is longer supported and users are encouraged to transition to the Customer Service Workspace to continue receiving updates and support.

For more information see:

  • https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customer-service/administer/migrate-oc-faq
  • https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dynamics365/customer-service/implement/deprecations-customer-service

name: Postman
description:
Postman is a popular API testing tool. Recent changes to the tool make it a security concern and consequently it is no longer approved for any use. Newer versions of both the paid and free versions sync API calls to the cloud. This exposes secrets such as keys, tokens and passwords. Please use one of these alternative tools:
  • Insomnium (not Insomnia)
  • Bruno
  • SoapUI Pro

name: PPM (legacy)
description: PPM is being rewritten from the ground-up to move away from IBM Case Manager and will have a very different API surface area. Move away from PPM's integrations towards Product Deliverable Hub.

name: Proofpoint Email and O365 email for bulk system or testing
PRTG
description: This is device monitoring tool that the MTC has integrated into Service Now for alerting purposes. It will be replaced by Dynatrace by end of year 2024.

name: PTH Self Service Renderer (SSR) and SSR API
description: The SSR API and renderer are used to pull content from LDS Publisher and render it on consuming websites. This was a commonly used solution before the Brightspot CMS was introduced. This particular implementation has been managed by the Priesthood Publishing team and needs to be retired.

name: Rename sharepoint: remove "lds" from name
description:
The SharePoint site is not going away, but it is being renamed.
office365lds.sharepoint.com and OneDrive (office365lds-my.sharepoint.com) will be changing to churchofjesuschrist.sharepoint.com and churchofjesuschrist-my.sharepoint.com

All Microsoft properties' URLs will be changed as part of the migration.  All other properties including Jira will require manual adjustment.

The new URL will not be available prior to the End of Life date, so plan to make your updates on that date.

Ask questions here:
https://teams.microsoft.com/l/team/19%3A63d377f131e044acae8611d75c11b2c1%40thread.skype/conversations?groupId=78ebe81a-2cea-4839-8c4c-3c406e627ed1&tenantId=61e6eeb3-5fd7-4aaa-ae3c-61e8deb09b79

name: Retire Insomnium
description: The Insomnium repository was archived by the owner on Jul 19, 2024. It is now read-only and should be considered abandoned.

name: Scalefunder
description: Scalefunder is used by Philanthropies for donation collection. It will be replaced by GiveCampus.

name: SMTP Relay
description: License will not be renewed.

name: SolarWinds
description: Monitoring solution for infrastructure, being deprecated for Dynatrace

name: SQL Server 2014, 2016, 2017, 2019
description: SQL Server 2022 introduced authentication with Entra ID.  With the movement off of Active Directory on-prem, we will need to migrate to SQL Server 2022+.

name: TeamViewer
description:
TeamViewer will be blocked by BeyondTrust sometime around mid-October. Per the endpoint security committee, remote access support tools are being consolidated under the BeyondTrust Remote Support tool. 

 

For questions regarding the block decision and implementation, contact Jeff Carpenter. For questions around migration to BeyondTrust Remote Support, contact Frank (Ronald) Nelson.

name: ThankView
description: ThankView is used by Philanthropies for donation collection. It will be replaced by GiveCampus.

name: WAM/ Header-based authentication/authorization (WAMosaurus and F5 APM implementations)
Windows 10 (End of Life / End of Support)
description: Windows 10 will reach the end of support on October 14, 2025. At this point technical assistance, feature updates and security updates will no longer be provided. If you have devices running Windows 10, we recommend upgrading them to Windows 11- a more current, in-service, and supported Windows release. If devices do not meet the technical requirements to run on Windows 11, we recommend that you replace the device with one that supports Windows 11.

name: WordPress
description:
WordPress has frequently been utilized to produce rapid-release internet facing applications due to its ease of use.  This made WordPress most popular in Church areas or in other groups without dedicated development resources.  Its accessibility came at the cost of poor or absent security considerations.

Historically, easy alternatives meeting the needs of WordPress were not available at the Church.  But, with simplified offerings from approved and centrally-managed technologies such as BrightSpot, there are now simple and secure options available.  As such, WordPress is not approved technology, but the attached document provides interim best practices for implementation while migrating to an approved solution.

name: Generative AI
description: Generative AI refers to AI algorithms that generate new content based on existing content. They can be used to generate images, text, and code. Some common use cases for generative AI are chatbots, summarizing data, generating content (code, text, images, videos), and translating text. Because of the way generative AI models are designed, there is potential for them to return incorrect, misleading, or biased results. Intellectual property rights are not well understood for input or output from generative AI models.

name: Confidential Computing
description: Confidential computing is the protection of data in-use with a hardware-based Trusted Execution Environment (TEE). A TEE is a secure area of the main processor where code and data can be loaded. It helps protect the confidentiality and integrity of data while it is in use. Confidential computing works in conjunction with security controls for encrypting data at rest and in transit to protect data while it is in use in memory.

name: Observability
description: Observability in software applications is the ability to understand what is happening and have the data to quickly resolve problems. Software is becoming increasingly more complex, and data is needed to understand dependencies between microservices or cloud-native components. Observability is an evolution of traditional monitoring techniques to instrument the code to emit sufficient telemetry, correlate the telemetry between systems, and account for dependencies that may result in unexpected errors. OpenTelemetry has created a standard for collecting telemetry, including vendor-agnostic SDKs and APIs. This standard has been adopted by many observability platforms, including Splunk and AppDynamics.

name: Software Bill of Materials (SBOM)
description: A Software Bill of Materials (SBOM) is an inventory for a software application, including all the third-party packages that make up the application. It provides visibility to help organizations better understand what is being used and where there could be risks. It helps identify applications that are impacted by critical vulnerabilities. It helps identify risks associated with software licenses for the third-party packages that are being used.

name: Cloud-native Architecture
description: Cloud-native architecture is the set of architecture patterns that take advantage of the full capabilities of cloud platforms. Typically, a lift-and-shift of an on-prem application will not fully use the capabilities of cloud. AWS and Microsoft Azure have both published well-architected frameworks that provide details about how to architect systems for the cloud. The AWS well-architected framework includes six pillars: operational excellence, security, reliability, performance efficiency, cost optimization, and sustainability. The Microsoft Azure well-architected framework is similar, with five pillars: reliability, security, cost optimization, operational excellence, and performance efficiency.

name: Digital Accessibility
description: Digital accessibility is the practice of designing technology in a way that it can be accessed by all users, regardless of abilities. This practice is part of our architecture guiding principle to "meet users where they are".
